thread.title: Weezy the rescue dog falls in love with baby brother
thread.title_full: Weezy the rescue dog falls in love with baby brother | Daily Mail Online

author: Dailymail.com Reporter
title: Weezy the rescue dog falls in love with baby brother
text:
A rescue dog named Weezy who used to be afraid of everything is shaking off her nerves now she has a little brother to look out for.
Sarah Mavro shared the amazing story of her family's rescue dog, and the unlikely relationship she formed with her newborn baby, in an interview with the Dodo .
Mavro says that Weezy, an Italian Greyhound, was so fearful that her first family returned her to the Alberta, Canada, shelter where they adopted her after just one night.
Scroll down for video
A rescue dog named Weezy has learned to quell her nerves after her family welcomed a newborn baby boy name Evan
While Weezy has always been shy, she lets baby Evan cuddle her freely
Sarah Mavro's family adopted Weezy, an Italian Greyhound, about three years ago
When they first adopted Weezy, she was scared of flies, squeaky toys and people
Mavro and her family drove nearly two hours from their home in Edmonton, to adopt Weezy.
Since then, they have taken her under their wing and slowly she has adjusted to life with the Mavro family.
When they first adopted Weezy, Mavro says that even the sound of a fly would shake her.
Another family adopted Weezy before the Mavros, and that family returned her to the shelter after just one day because she was too fearful
Weezy has really opened up since Baby Evan was added to the Malvo family seven months ago
'[Baby Evan] is 7 months old now and she loves him even more than she loves us I think,' Mavro says. 'She will climb right up beside him and let him get all over her.'
Weezy's tongue hangs out because most of her teeth had to be pulled out
'She is still timid, especially with strangers, and very quiet,' Mavro tells The Dodo. 'Literally, a dying fly once kicked her out of her own cage.'
Weezy also hides in blankets like a little child.
In addition to her fear issues, Weezy's teeth were in bad shape when she was adopted and all but two had to be removed. So her tongue will often hang out of her mouth uncontrollably.
'She is still timid, especially with strangers, and very quiet,' Mavro said. 'Literally, a dying fly once kicked her out of her own cage.'
Weezy looks a little uncomfortable as she's treated to a bath by her owners
One of Weezy's favorite pastimes is to hide in a blanket
Things began to change though seven months ago, when Mavro brought home her newborn baby boy Evan.
Weezy has never been nervous around Evan and lets the baby cuddle her as much as he wants.
'He is seven months old now and she loves him even more than she loves us I think,' Mavro says. 'She will climb right up beside him and let him get all over her.'
